structured_data.name: Landslide Hazard Assessment for Situational Awareness (LHASA) Model
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable software (GitHub), web viewer, data archive (NASA DISC), code available upon request
structured_data.description: The Landslide Hazard Assessment for Situational Awareness (LHASA) Model, developed by NASA, maps areas of potential landslide hazard in real time. LHASA 2.0 improves upon LHASA 1.1 by incorporating global landslide inventories within a machine learning framework to estimate the relative probability of landslide occurrence, relying on variables like snow mass, soil moisture, slope, distance to faults, lithologic strength, and rainfall (current and antecedent from GPM IMERG, forecasted from GEOS-FP). It also estimates potential exposure of human population and roads and maps basins likely to experience post-fire debris flows. LHASA 1.1 uses IMERG precipitation data and a global landslide susceptibility map. Both versions are open-source and produced at a 1-km resolution.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Real-time (for LHASA 2.0 nowcast), historical landslide inventories for validation

decision_log.summary: CCRA plan for hazards/landslide (Global) with 54 structured queries.

decision_log.summary: The NASA GPM document is highly promising, detailing several global landslide datasets and models, including LHASA 2.0 with a 1-km resolution and links to data viewers and code. It directly addresses landslide hazards and even exposure. The Copernicus document has no content.
decision_log.reasoning: The NASA GPM document provides direct links to global landslide hazard and exposure data, including a viewer and open-source code, and specifies a 1-km resolution, which is suitable for extraction. The other document is empty.

decision_log.summary: The LHASA Model is highly relevant for landslide hazard assessment, providing real-time and historical data at a global 1-km resolution. It incorporates key variables for landslide susceptibility and even estimates potential exposure of human population and roads, which is a valuable addition for CCRA. The source (NASA) is highly credible.
decision_log.reasoning: The LHASA model is a highly relevant, credible, and complete dataset for global landslide hazard assessment. Its 1-km resolution and real-time capabilities make it an excellent resource for CCRA. The inclusion of some exposure indicators further strengthens its utility.
